items.title: Actor Kevin Spacey says he's living out of hotels after losing Hollywood roles
items.summary_auto: Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. In an interview with The Telegraph, Spacey said the financial hardship that followed has left him without a permanent home. While none of the allegations were proven in court, Spacey says the allegations have kept Hollywood at bay.

items.title: 'Quiet, piggy': As Trump berates female reporters, what's the breaking point?
items.summary_auto: It's certainly not the first time U.S. President Donald Trump has insulted a female reporter, but calling Bloomberg's Catherine Lucey 'piggy' on Air Force One, then berating ABC News' Mary Bruce a few days later has raised questions about just how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs.

items.title: Video showing mishandling of a dead body in Quebec City prompts coroner's investigation
items.summary_auto: The Quebec coroner's office has launched an internal investigation after a video circulated online showing a funeral transporter inappropriately moving a body.

items.title: U.K. government moves to ban inflated resale of tickets for entertainment and sports events
items.summary_auto: The U.K. government announced that it is banning the resale of concert, sports, and live event tickets above face value. Fans there could be saved from shelling out around $206 million annually for tickets.

items.title: Trump administration touts plan for new oil drilling off California, Florida
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration announced on Thursday new oil drilling off the California and Florida coasts for the first time in decades, advancing a project that critics say could harm coastal communities and ecosystems, as U.S. President Donald Trump seeks to expand U.S. oil production.

items.title: How one reporter’s question struck at the core of U.S.-Saudi relations | About That
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump defended Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during his Oval Office visit after an ABC News reporter asked about his connection to the 2018 assassination of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Andrew Chang breaks down what the exchange highlights about two key relationships: Trump and the media, and the U.S. and Saudi Arabia. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Border officers' union raises security concerns about use of automation during asylum intakes
items.summary_auto: The head of the union representing Canada’s border officers is suggesting the government's move toward automating the refugee claimant process is creating security gaps — allegations the Canada Border Services Agency is pushing back against.

items.title: Democratic vets in Congress warn about following unlawful military orders, which Trump calls seditious
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump has lashed out at six congressional Democrats who this week released a video to social media advising troops they can decline unlawful orders, branding it seditious behaviour.

items.title: Warner Music and Udio settle lawsuit, agree to build new AI music platform
items.summary_auto: The deal settles Warner's copyright infringement claims against AI music generation platform Udio, and will allow the platform to train its AI on licensed and authorized music from its artists. This agreement closely mirrors one signed weeks ago between Udio and Universal Music Group, and comes as AI generated songs and artists have been increasingly popping up on streaming platforms and rising on music charts.

items.title: Bell slashes nearly 700 jobs in latest round of layoffs
items.summary_auto: Bell Canada says it's cutting about 690 employees, mostly managers, to help reduce debt and drive growth. The cuts follow thousands of company layoffs last year.

items.title: Freeland will move to U.K. for new job as CEO of Rhodes Trust educational charity
items.summary_auto: Liberal MP Chrystia Freeland will move to Oxford, England, to take on a new position next summer administering the Rhodes Trust, the educational charity says.

items.title: Ontario minor hockey investigating after coaches get in fist fight at U13 game
items.summary_auto: All bench staff on both teams have been suspended indefinitely pending a hearing, the OMHA told CBC News.

items.title: Rising cost of food is changing how Canadians eat, survey shows
items.summary_auto: According to the latest edition of the Canadian Food Sentiment Index, four out of every five people surveyed said food is their top expense pressure.

items.title: Bill restoring citizenship for 'Lost Canadians' becomes law
items.summary_auto: The "Lost Canadians" legislation, which aims to fix Canada's unconstitutional citizenship by descent rules, passed in the Senate Wednesday and received royal assent Thursday afternoon.

items.title: Huskies hunt for Vanier Cup breakthrough in home province against high-flying Carabins
items.summary_auto: The Canada West champion Saskatchewan Huskies take the field at Mosaic Stadium in their home province against RSEQ victor Montreal Carabins in the 60th installment on the Vanier Cup on Saturday.

items.title: CDC adopts Robert F. Kennedy's anti-vaccine views on autism website
items.summary_auto: A U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website has been changed to contradict the longtime scientific conclusion that vaccines do not cause autism, spurring outrage among a number of public health and autism experts.

items.title: City investigating after videos show Toronto contractor driving snowplow through pro-Palestinian demonstration
items.summary_auto: “Thank goodness no one was hurt,” Mayor Olivia Chow told reporters before confirming city staff have been asked to investigate incident.

items.title: Man charged after Winnipeg nurse sexually assaulted in parkade
items.summary_auto: A man has been charged with sexual assault after a Winnipeg hospital nurse was attacked in a parkade, police say.

items.title: Delay in COVID-19 lockdowns in U.K. resulted in some 23,000 more deaths: public inquiry
items.summary_auto: Former British prime minister Boris Johnson oversaw a "toxic," "chaotic" and dithering response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a delay in locking the country down resulting in about 23,000 more deaths, a report by a public inquiry concluded on Thursday.

items.title: This moss survived 9 months outside the International Space Station in the harshness of space
items.summary_auto: Space is a harsh environment: it's a vacuum with freezing temperatures, super high ultraviolet radiation and, of course, almost no oxygen. But Japanese researchers have found a type of moss that doesn’t really care about much of that.

items.title: Bill passes to fast-track transmission line in northern B.C.
items.summary_auto: A bill to fast-track construction of the multibillion-dollar North Coast Transmission Line passed third reading Thursday, despite attempts by the B.C. Conservatives and B.C. Greens to stall or amend it.

items.title: Children's advocates want new online harms legislation before the end of the year
items.summary_auto: A national coalition of advocacy groups, health-care organizations and a telecommunications company have come together to demand the federal government reintroduce legislation to protect children from online exploitation.

items.title: Advocates calling for improved pain management for IUD insertions in B.C.
items.summary_auto: For some, the procedure is no problem. For others, it’s extremely painful.

items.title: Calgary advocate leads national push for revival of Online Harms Act to protect kids
items.summary_auto: A Calgary woman is leading a national push to have the federal government revive legislation aimed at protecting people — especially children — from harmful content online.

items.title: Residents in this rural B.C. community receive a prescription to exercise at a rec centre
items.summary_auto: Ian Walters received a prescription from his paramedical nurse this past summer, but instead of receiving a pill, he was given a pass to the Similkameen Recreation Centre in Keremeos, B.C., to use the gym and take part in programming.

items.title: New petition attempts to recognize Afghanistan veterans with the Victoria Cross
items.summary_auto: The Victoria Cross, Canada’s highest military honour, hasn’t been awarded to a Canadian soldier since the Second World War. Now, a petition before the House of Commons meant to rectify that situation has reached more than 16,000 signatures.

items.title: 2 dead, child critically injured, after Brampton house fire
items.summary_auto: Two adults are dead after an overnight house fire in Brampton that also left four others, including a child, in critical condition. Police said they're still looking for three people who lived in the building.

items.title: This community fridge is spending $6,000 per month on food, and it's still not enough
items.summary_auto: A Dartmouth, volunteer-run organization says it's now buying nearly $6,000 worth of food each month for people to take for free from its community fridge.

items.title: St. John's man fears he'll be 'back on the street' after being evicted from social housing
items.summary_auto: When Kyle Harbin moved from a private shelter to a shared house in the heart of St. John’s, he hoped for stability, and a transition into a new, comfortable life. Two years later, he's being evicted.

items.title: Government 'sneakily' moving to avoid paying veterans over federal error, Conservatives say
She lost 5 children during the war in Gaza — now she’s raising 36 grandkids in a tent
items.summary_auto: Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”

items.title: Government seeks to retroactively change law, potentially avoiding paying veterans over federal error
items.summary_auto: The Carney government’s budget legislation contains an amendment that lawyers representing veterans say is a bid to cover up a decades-long error that led to overcharging for long-term care.

items.title: Do kids still want toys? Toy stores are struggling, but don't just blame screens
items.summary_auto: In the age of screens, amid reports of retail stores struggling and studies suggesting that all kids want for Christmas are Robux, what does the future hold for the toy industry?
